Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stable Isotopes of Ice in the Transition and Glacial Sections of the WAIS Divide Deep Ice Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
Steig/1043092

This award supports a project to contribute one of the cornerstone analyses, stable isotopes of ice (Delta-D, Delta-O18) to the ongoing West Antarctic Ice Sheet Divide (WAIS) deep ice core. The WAIS Divide drilling project, a multi-institution project to obtain a continuous high resolution ice core record from central West Antarctica, reached a depth of 2560 m in early 2010; it is expected to take one or two more field seasons to reach the ice sheet bed (~3300 m), plus an additional four seasons for borehole logging and other activities including proposed replicate coring. The current proposal requests support to complete analyses on the WAIS Divide core to the base, where the age will be ~100,000 years or more. These analyses will form the basis for the investigation of a number of outstanding questions in climate and glaciology during the last glacial period, focused on the dynamics of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and the relationship of West Antarctic climate to that of the Northern polar regions, the tropical Pacific, and the rest of the globe, on time scales ranging from years to tens of thousands of years. One new aspect of this work is the growing expertise at the University of Washington in climate modeling with isotope-tracer-enabled general circulation models, which will aid in the interpretation of the data. Another major new aspect is the completion and use of a high-resolution, semi-automated sampling system at the University of Colorado, which will permit the continuous analysis of isotope ratios via laser spectroscopy, at an effective resolution of ~2 cm or less, providing inter-annual time resolution for most of the core. Because continuous flow analyses of stable ice isotopes is a relatively new measurement, we will complement them with parallel measurements, every ~10-20 m, using traditional discrete sampling and analysis by mass spectrometry at the University of Washington. The intellectual merit and the overarching goal of the work are to see Inland WAIS become the reference ice isotope record for West Antarctica. The broader impacts of the work are that the data generated in this project pertain directly to policy-relevant and immediate questions of the stability of the West Antarctic ice sheet, and thus past and future changes in sea level, as well as the nature of climate change in the high southern latitudes. The project will also contribute to the development of modern isotope analysis techniques using laser spectroscopy, with applications well beyond ice cores. The project will involve a graduate student and postdoc who will work with both P.I.s, and spend time at both institutions. Data will be made available rapidly through the Antarctic Glaciological Data Center, for use by other researchers and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The measurements of water isotopes in the WAIS Divide ice core (WDC) were completed in June 2014. The full data set consists of 3,406 meters of ice and dates to over 68,000 years before present. The measurements were achieved using a continuous flow analysis (CFA) system. The full ice core record is sampled at millimeter resolution. This makes WDC the highest-resolution and longest continuously measured ice core yet recovered from Antarctica, and the first ice core ever to be sampled from surface to basal ice for stable ice isotopes at such a high resolution.

 

Such high-resolution data required new tools to fully utilize the rich data set. To completely interpret the high-resolution data, we developed mixing and diffusion corrections, which were then applied to the measured data to better reconstruct the original isotopic signal in fresh snow. Taken together, these corrections allow for an estimate of the original isotopic signal as it occurred at the surface of the ice sheet through time.

 

The annual signal persists until about 16,000 years ago. Sub-annual signals can be recovered throughout the Holocene, yielding annually resolved records of summer and winter temperatures, and seasonality, over the last 16,000 years. Signals at periods of 3 years and greater persist throughout the entire record. This allowed for an analysis of high-frequency signals for the last 68,000 years, notably frequencies in the classic El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) band (e.g. 3-7 years) throughout the last glacial-interglacial cycle.

 

An analysis of the extent of diffusion through time from 0 to 29,000 years ago yielded unexpected results during the glacial-interglacial transition. An enhanced diffusion interval was observed between about 18,000 to 16,500 years ago. During this interval, diffusion lengths nearly doubled, a finding that cannot be explained by the current generation of diffusion models.

 

The signals recovered, including typical ENSO frequencies, showed elevated strength in the glacial, reduced strength in the Holocene, and an abrupt, centennial scale decline occurring around 16,200 years ago.  Modeling this signal revealed that among many different possible forcing mechanisms – changes in the Earth’s orbit, greenhouse gas, and continental ice sheets - the effect of a decreasing Laurentide Ice Sheet (lowered height) likely altered the northern jet stream, which altered air circulation in the tropical Pacific, which in turn influenced West Antarctic climate.

 

During the Holocene, we were able to reconstruct annual, summer maximum, winter minimum, and total seasonal water isotope signals. We found that the summer maximum trends with maximum yearly insolation at 50 degrees South, with millennial variability superimposed on the smoother insolation change. This finding is reasonable, but had never been observed before without the high frequency data made possible by CFA analysis. The winter minimum exhibits no clear time trend, except for millennial variability. These high-frequency results will improve climate models in an area of the globe that not well covered by detailed, high-frequency observations of temperatures.

 

The use of CFA and laser absorption spectrometry (CFA-LAS) to measure stable isotopes in ice cores has the added benefit of producing time series that are sufficiently data rich to apply techniques of information theory and time series analysis that were not possible using less densely sampled cores. The Shannon entropy rate measures the average rate at which new information, unrelated to anything in the past, is produced by the system that generated the time series. If that production rate is very low, the current observation contains a lot of information about the past and the signal is, in theory, perfectly predictable. If that production rate is very high, all of the information in the observation is completely new and the past tells one nothing about the future. The rate at which new information appears in a time series has been shown to be an effective method for signaling regime shifts in a data series. For example, epileptic seizures can be detected in EEG signals and human voices can be recognized in an otherwise noisy audio signal. This quantity allows one to explore when new information is injected into the climate system, which is critically important in understanding the underlying physical processes that control this complex system.

 

The most interesting climate finding in the entropy results is what is not seen, that is, there are no clear increases in entropy accompanying the oscillations in isotopes during the glacial period. These oscillations are the Southern Hemisphere expression of Dansgaard-Oeschger events, the canonical expression of abrupt climate changes. That these changes occur without an increase in entropy implies that they are predictable from the previous data, and not the result of new information being injected into the climate system. If true, this finding would have profound impact on how we view abrupt climate change and the potential to predict these highly disruptive changes in advance.
